sub_title: Professor (Chair - Inclusion and Motivation in Health Professions Education) and Research Programme Leader for Research in Education
summary:
I have worked in a teaching role with senior responsibilities (on the verge of becoming an Associate Professor) in an illustrious medical college in India for 7 years after my post-graduation in medicine. In 2008 I took up the opportunity to invest in pursuing a PhD in medical education in the Netherlands, which was not then possible in India. 
I have been instrumental in setting up the department of Research in Education at VUmc School of Medical Sciences in 2012, and headed this department until 2020. I currently work as Professor on Inclusion and Motivation in Health Professions Education and Research Programme Leader at Research in Education at Amsterdam UMC-location Vrije Universiteit. I currently conduct direct supervision of 13 PhD students; 6 PhD students have graduated from my programme. I have been able to secure external funding (>1 million Euros) for research. My vison for education is to develop ‘students for life’.
My work in educational practice includes being a small group instructor in the Faculty of Medicine Vrije Universiteit Bachelor students, research internship coordinator for Research in Education for Faculty of Medicine Vrije Universiteit Master students, being a member of Committee Research Internships at Faculty of Medicine Vrije Universiteit and practical application of the research being done in my department into the curricular practices, serving as an Examination Board member (2013-2020), advising on important educational activities and developing a training course for students to obtain a teaching qualification.
My most significant achievements include being awarded the “NVMO Best PhD Thesis Prize 2014” in medical education, being welcomed as an International Scholar on Self-Determination Theory of motivation, being the Chief Organizer of the 7th International Self-determination Theory Conference, and being chosen for the Fellowship of Karolinska Institute Prize for Research In Medical Education 2019. 
I was a Visiting Professor at University of Indonesia for their Master of Medical Education programme from  2020 to 2021. I am a member of the Executive Committee of the Association of Medical Education in Europe (AMEE) and Chair-Elect of the AMEE Fellowship Committee..

awards.title: NRO Practice-oriented research (Prakrijkgericht onderzoek) grant
awards.description: A grant of 275000 Euros for the project “Unintended effects of selection on medical student and applicant diversity: What can we do about this?”. This a consortium grant. The project consortium consists of Prof. Dr. Gerda Croiset, Dr. Rashmi Kusurkar & Dr. Anouk Wouters (VUmc), Prof. Dr. Walther van den Broek(Erasmus MC), Prof. Dr. Heleen Miedema (University of Twente), Andries Koster & Renske van Gestel (UU Pharmaceutical Sciences) and Jan Hindrik Ravesloot (AMC).

awards.title: Dutch Medical education Association (NVMO) Best Thesis 2014 Award
awards.description:
This prize is awarded every two years by the Dutch Medical Education Association (NVMO) for all theses in medical education in the Netherlands and Belgium. In the years 2012 and 2013, 45-50 medical education theses were completed. Out of these 10 received a nomination for this prize from their PhD guides. An international jury judged all these submitted theses. This year the jury comprised of:

 

Prof. Dr. Olle ten Cate (University of Utrecht, the Netherlands)
Prof. Dr. Anselme Derese (University of Gent, Belgium)
Dr. Marjan Govaerts (University of Maastricht, the Netherlands)
Prof. Dr. Patricia O’Sullivan (University of California San Francisco, USA)
Prof. Dr. Steven Durning (Unified Services University, Bethesda Maryland, USA) 

The criteria for judgement were quality of the work (a variety of methods used for research, writing style, language, clarity), number of publications at the time of PhD defence, number of citations, whether there was a theoretical basis for the work, did the work add to the literature at the conceptual level, did it have applications for practitioners and impact of the work for further research.
